document.title: Specification of Commata, which is just another C++14 CSV parser

section.name: General
section.p: This document describes the specifications of Commata, which is a header-only library in C++14 to handle formatted texts, such as CSV texts.

In this document, many terms and names introduced in ISO C++14 standard are referred without notice. “Unspecified behavior,” “DefaultConstructible requirements,” “formatted output function,” “<string>” (as a header name) and “std::string” are the examples.
The normativity of the specifications on this document is the same as the normativity of the description of the ISO C++14 standard for its conforming standard library implementations except that:

ul.li: class templates and function templates shall not have any additional template parameters no matter whether they have their default template-arguments, and

member templates shall not have any additional template parameters no matter whether they have their default template arguments, except that constructor templates can have ones with their default template arguments.
member function templates shall not have any additional parameters no matter whether they have their default arguments.

section.name: Using Commata
section.p: A translation unit may include headers described in this document in any order. Each may be included more than once, with no effect different from being included exactly once.

A translation unit shall include a header described in this document only outside of any external declaration or definition, and shall include the header lexically before the first reference in that translation unit to any of the entities declared in that header.
A translation unit shall not define a macro whose name meets one of the following before a point of an #include preprocessor directive which includes a header described in this document:

ul.li: it consists only of one uppercase alphabetic letter,
it begins with a lowercase alphabetic letter,

it consists only of alphabetic letters and decimal digit characters, the number of the latter of which may possibly be zero, contains both of an uppercase alphabetic letter and a lowercase one, and begins with an uppercase one, or
it begins with COMMATA_.

section.p: Headers described in this document may define macros whose name begin with COMMATA_ and may not define any macros with other names.

section.name: Basic concepts
section.p: Commata consists of two loosely-coupled parts following:

ul.li: the parser, which reads a sequence of char-like objects in a certain format such as a CSV text () from a stream or a stream buffer and emits events to a handler, which is called a text handler, and
default text handlers, objects of which receive events from the parser and do some default operation on them.

section.p: Due to this loosely-coupled nature, you can implement your own new text handler and make the parser emit events to an object of it. The requrements that the parser need text handlers to meet are bundled as the TextHandler requirements ().

section.name: Text tables
section.p: Events that text handlers receive from the parser conform the text table model following:

ul.li: Each text table has its char type that is a char-like type.
A text table is a sequence of text records.
A text record is a sequence of text fields.
Each text field has its text value, which is a sequence of the char type objects.

section.name: CSV texts
section.p: The CSV parser of Commata () conforms the CSV text model following:

ul.li: A CSV text is a representation of a text table () as a sequence of objects whose type is the char type of the text table.
Each CSV text has its char type that is equal to the char type of the text table.
Each text field of a text table represented as a CSV text is either of a quoted field or a unquoted field.

A quoted field is represented as a sequence of the char type objects that starts with a double quote and ends with a double quote. Its representation cannot contain odd number of contiguous double quotes after the the starting double quote and before the ending double quote.
An unquoted field is represented as a sequence of the char type objects that does not contain any double quotes, commas and line breaks.

The text value of a quoted field is defined as follows:
first make a copy of the sequence of characters of the range [the next character of the starting double quote, the previous character of the ending double quote],
then replace every occurrence of two contiguous double quotes in it into one double quote.
The text value of an unquoted field is the representation as a sequence of the char type objects itself.

In a CSV text, each text record is represented as a comma-delimited sequence of representations of its text fields. The representation of the final text field in a text record is not followed by a comma.
In a CSV text, the representations of its text records are delimited by a line break. The representation of the final record is or is not followed by a line break.

Each line break is either of CR, LF, or CRLF where CR is a carrage return character, LF is a line feed (or new-line) character, and CRLF is a two-character sequence the first character of which is CR and the second is LF.
A record index of a text record in a text table is a number i where the record is the i-th record in the text table. It depends on situation whether i is zero-based or one-based.
A field index of a text field in a text record is a number j where the field is the j-th field in the text record. It depends on situation whether j is zero-based or one-based.
A line or physical line in a sequence of char-like objects is a sequence of characters delimited by line breaks. It does not contain any line breaks in it.
A column or physical column in a sequence of char-like objects is a bundle of the same distant characters from the first character of each line.

A position or physical position of a character in a sequence of char-like objects is the pair of m and n where the character belongs to the m-th line and the n-th column. It depends on situation whether m and n are zero-based or one-based.

section.name: Extraction of records into another stream
General
section.p: Commata offers two class templates record_extractor () and record_extractor_with_indexed_key (), whose instances meet TextHandler requirements (), as simple facilities to reduce text records.

An object of an instance of record_extractor or record_extractor_with_indexed_key receives parsing events from a parser and forwards some qualified records into another stream. Whether a record is qualified to be forwarded or not is decided by the value of its field at the target field index. The target field index can be given explicitly by the program (with record_extractor_with_indexed_key), or can be decided in reference to the first one record (with record_extractor).
A record that can not be decided whether it is qualified to be forwarded or not due to non-existence of the field at the target field index shall cause an exception.
An object of an instance of record_extractor or record_extractor_with_indexed_key can not be reused; that is, it can receive the parsing events that the parser emits only once.
In this subclause, the first one record of a CSV text is called its header record.

section.name: Class template record_extractor
section.p: An instance of record_extractor is a type that meets TextHandler requirements () for the template parameter Ch.

An object of it first scans the header record to decide the target field index, and then scan the all non-header records to decide whether the record is forwarded to the stream in terms of their values of the field at the target field index.
When the target field index is left undecided after the scanning of the header record finished, an exception shall be thrown.
FieldNamePred and FieldValuePred shall be binary predicate types for two const char* parameters.

section.name: Class template basic_stored_table overview
section.p: The class template basic_stored_table is a facility to make an in-memory image of text values arranged two-dimensionally.

The template parameter Content shall be a sequence container type of a sequence container type of basic_stored_value<Ch, Tr> () for some Ch and Tr. Note that std::array and std::forward_list do not qualify because they lack some essential functionalities of sequence containers.
The template parameter Allocator shall meet the Allocator requirements for Content.

section.name: basic_stored_table constituents
section.p: An object of basic_stored_table<Content, Allocator> consists of the four following constituents:

ul.li: a content, whose type is Content and that is a sequence container object of sequence container objects of text values that are objects of basic_stored_value<Ch, Tr> () for some Ch and Tr,
a store, which is a bundle of buffers each one of which is an array of Ch and contains memory referenced by the text values in the content,
an allocator, whose type is Allocator and that is used to allocate and construct the content and to allocate memories required by the store and any other operations, and
a buffer size, whose type is std::size_t and that is used as the least amount of Ch in one memory allocation.

section.p: An object of an instance of basic_stored_table is able not to have its content.
The store of an object of basic_stored_table marks one buffer in it as its current buffer when it is not empty; that is, when it has at least one buffer.

section.name: Definitions
section.p: An object of an instance of basic_stored_table without its content is called singular.
The value type of an object of an instance of basic_stored_table<Content, Allocator> denotes typename Content::value_type::value_type, whose type is an instance of basic_stored_value.
Contained values of an object t of an instance T of basic_stored_table denotes the objects of the value type in the content of t.
An object v of a value type is called backed by an object t of an instance of basic_stored_table if:

ul.li: v.empty() is not false, or
the range [v.cbegin(), v.cend()] resides in a buffer in the store of t, and *v.cend() is equal to Ch().

section.p: An object of an instance of basic_stored_table is called complete if none of its contained values is not backed by it. Note that a singular object of an instance of basic_stored_table is also complete because it has no contained values.

section.name: General requirements and postconditions
section.p: The consequence of accessing to the content of a singular basic_stored_table object is undefined. A singular object can be assigned, destroyed, copied from or moved from. A singular object has a store, an allocator, and a buffer size similarly to non-singular objects.

All member functions of basic_stored_table and all non-member functions declared in this header () that take at least one parameter whose cv-unqualified type is (possibly a reference to) an instance of basic_stored_table require that the following conditions meet:

ul.li: all participating basic_stored_table objects are complete, and
no two of the contained values of the participating basic_stored_table objects overlap.

section.p: And they meet the following postconditions:

ul.li: all participating basic_stored_table objects shall be complete,
no two of the contained values of the participating basic_stored_table objects shall overlap, and
the states of the participating basic_stored_table objects shall not be changed if the call exits via an exception.

section.p: All non-const member functions of basic_stored_table and all non-member functions declared in this header () that take at least one parameter whose type is a reference to a non-const basic_stored_table<Ch, Tr> for some Ch and Tr may change the current buffer marks of the participating non-const basic_stored_table objects.

section.name: Class template stored_table_builder
section.p: The class template stored_table_builder is a tool to create an image of a table of a text into a basic_stored_table () object, which is called the targeted object. An instantiation of it satisfies the TextHandler requirements () for char_type. An object of an instantiation of it can not be reused; that is, it can receive the parsing events that the parser emits only once.
The template parameters Content and Allocator shall be types that make basic_stored_table<Content, Allocator> a valid type.

The template parameter Options is a bitmask to control the behavior of the builder. Its effects are described in . In it, c denotes an lvalue reference to content() of the targeted object and s does the value that c.size() had before the parsing. Indices i and j are zero-based. In addition, operator[] and operator+ are used on types that do not necessarily have them well-defined. In these cases, the semaintics of d[n] and p + n is the same as that of *std::next(d.begin(), n) and std::next(p, n) respectively.

tr.td: The value of the j-th field of the i-th record of the text shall be arranged into c[s + i][j].

The value of the j-th field of the i-th record of the text shall be arranged into c[j][s + i]. On each arrangement, the range [c[j].begin() + e, c[j].begin() + (s + i)) shall be filled by empty values where e is the value that c[j].size() had before the arrangement.

section.p: After parsing, even when it has exited via an exception, the targeted object shall be complete and not singular ().

section.name: General
section.p: Commata offers a table scanner class template, whose name is basic_table_scanner (), whose instances meet the TextHandler requirements () as a simple facility for one-pass scanning of texts.

A table scanner object can hold a body field scanner object for each field to which it forwards the field values, and it can hold a record-end scanner object to which it noitifies the end-of-record events.

In addition, a table scanner object can be configured to recognize some first records as “header” records. It can simply ignore the header records or can forward the field values in the header to a header field scanner object it holds optionally.

Properties that the type of the body field scanners shall meet, type of the record-end scanners shall meet, and the type of the header field scanners shall meet are bundled as the BodyFieldScanner, the RecordEndScanner and the HeaderFieldScanner requirements respectively.

section.name: General
section.p: The Commata library offers three default body field scanner types that meet the BodyFieldScanner requirements (): arithmetic_field_translator (), locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator () and string_field_translator ().
An object of these types translates a field value into a value of its target type and forwards it into its installed sink.
Behaviors of these default body scanner objects can be customized through the three concepts: FieldTranslatorSink (), SkippingHandler () and ConversionErrorHandler ().

ul.li: if S is an output iterator type, to evaluate *s = rt,
otherwise, to evaluate s(rt).

section.p: The locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator class template provides an implementation for arithmetic types that meets the BodyFieldScanner requirements () in addition to the arithmetic_field_translator class template (). The difference is that an object of locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator can correctly handle the decimal radix separator character and the digit group separator character that differ from those of the C-language locale.

T is the target type () and shall be either of char, signed char, unsigned char, short, unsigned short, int, unsigned, long, unsigned long, long long, unsigned long long, float, or double. Sink shall be a FieldTranslatorSink type for the type T (). The template parameter SkippingHandler shall be a SkippingHandler type for the type T (). The template parameter ConversionErrorHandler shall be a ConversionErrorHandler type for the type T ().

code-item.code: explicit locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator( Sink sink, const std::locale& loc, SkippingHandler handle_skipping = SkippingHandler(), ConversionErrorHandler handle_conversion_error = ConversionErrorHandler());
code-item.effects: Initializes a object of locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator that holds copies of sink, loc, handle_skipping and handle_conversion_error as the field translator sink object, the locale object, the skipping handler object and the conversion error handler object respectively.

code-item.code: locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator( locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator&& other) noexcept(see below);
code-item.effects: Initializes a object of locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator that holds a field translator sink object, a locale object, a skipping handler object and a conversion error handler object initialized with xvalues of the corresponding objects of other.
code-item.remark: The expression inside noexcept is equivalent to std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<Sink>::value && std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<SkippingHandler>::value && std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<ConversionErrorHandler>::value. When this constructor exits via an exception, other will be placed in an unspecified state.

code-item.code: const SkippingHandler& get_skipping_handler() const noexcept; SkippingHandler& get_skipping_handler() noexcept;
code-item.returns: A reference of the skipping handler held by *this.

code-item.code: const ConversionErrorHandler& get_conversion_error_handler() const noexcept; ConversionErrorHandler& get_conversion_error_handler() noexcept;
code-item.returns: A reference of the conversion error handler held by *this.

section.name: locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator members to meet the BodyFieldScanner requirements

code-item.code: template <class Ch> void field_value(Ch* begin, Ch* end);
code-item.requires: Ch shall be char or wchar_t.
code-item.effects: If the specified locale has a non-empty grouping spec of the numeric output, removes all digit group separator characters of the specified locale in the range [begin, end) in place. Replaces the decimal radix separator character of the specified locale in the resulted range on its first occurrence in place with the decimal radix separator character of the C-language locale. Then calls a parsing function with the resulted range and put a value into the field translator sink as if a arithmetic_field_translator () object does.
code-item.remark: Suppose that npf is std::use_facet<std::numpunct<Ch>>(l) where l is the specified locale. The grouping spec of the numeric output of it is npf.grouping(). The digit group separator character of the specified locale is npf.thousands_sep(). The decimal radix separator character of it is npf.decimal_point(). The decimal radix separator character of the C-language locale is *std::localeconv()->decimal_point conditionally widen with std::btowc to get a value of the type Ch.

code-item.code: void field_skipped();
code-item.effects: Evaluates sh() and puts the result into the field translator sink where sh is the skipping handler.

section.name: Class template string_field_translator
section.p: The string_field_translator class template provides a simple implementation for the standard string type that meets the BodyFieldScanner requirements (). Its target type () is std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Alloc>.

Sink shall be a FieldTranslatorSink type for std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Alloc> (). The template parameter SkippingHandler shall be a SkippingHandler type for the type std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Alloc> ().

code-item.code: string_field_translator(Sink sink, SkippingHandler handle_skipping = SkippingHandler());
code-item.requires: Allocator shall be DefaultConstructible.
code-item.effects: Initializes a object of string_field_translator that holds a default-constructed Allocator object as its allocator, and copies of sink and handle_skipping as the field translator sink object and the skipping handler object respectively.

code-item.code: string_field_translator(std::allocator_arg_t, const Allocator& alloc, Sink sink, SkippingHandler handle_skipping = SkippingHandler());
code-item.effects: Initializes a object of string_field_translator that holds copies of alloc, sink and handle_skipping as the allocator object, the field translator sink object and the skipping handler object respectively.

code-item.code: string_field_translator(string_field_translator&& other) noexcept(see below);
code-item.effects: Initializes a object of string_field_translator that holds an allocator object, a field translator sink object, and a skipping handler object initialized with xvalues of the corresponding objects of other.
code-item.remark: The expression inside noexcept is equivalent to std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<Sink>::value && std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<SkippingHandler>::value. When this constructor exits via an exception, other will be placed in an unspecified state.

code-item.code: allocator_type get_allocator() const noexcept;
code-item.returns: A copy of the allocator object used to construct the string.

code-item.code: const SkippingHandler& get_skipping_handler() const noexcept; SkippingHandler& get_skipping_handler() noexcept;
code-item.returns: A reference of the skipping handler held by *this.

section.name: string_field_translator members to meet the BodyFieldScanner requirements

code-item.code: void field_value(const Ch* begin, const Ch* end);
code-item.effects: Puts std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Alloc>(begin, end, get_allocator()) into the field translator sink.

code-item.code: void field_value(std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Alloc>&& value);
code-item.effects: If value.get_allocator() == get_allocator(), puts std::move(value) into the field translator sink. Otherwise, calls field_value(value.c_str(), value.c_str() + value.size()).

code-item.code: void field_skipped();
code-item.effects: Evaluates sh() and puts the result into the field translator sink where sh is the skipping handler.

section.name: Creation of default field scanners
section.p: In this subclause, a type S is deemed to be an acceptable sink of a type T if:

ul.li: std::iterator_traits<S>::iterator_category is a type equal to std::output_iterator_tag, std::forward_iterator_tag, or their derived type; or
s(t) is a valid expression where s is an lvalue of S and t is an rvalue of T.

code-item.code: template <class T, class Sink, class... Appendices> see below make_field_translator(Sink sink, Appendices&&... appendices);
code-item.returns:
R(std::move(sink), std::forward<Appendices>(appendices)...) where the type R is decided as follows:
If T is std::basic_string<Ch, Tr, Allocator> for a certain combination of Ch, Tr and Allocator, string_field_translator<Sink, Ch, Tr, Allocator, Appendices...>,
otherwise, if the reference-removed type of the first type of Appendices is a possibly cv-qualified std::locale or its derived type, locale_based_arithmetic_field_translator<T, Sink, TailOfAppendices...> where TailOfAppendices... represents the types of Appendices... without its first type,
otherwise, arithmetic_field_translator<T, Sink, Appendices...>.
code-item.remark: This overload shall not participate in overload resolution unless Sink is deemed to be an acceptable sink of T.

code-item.returns: string_field_translator<Sink, typename T::value_type, typename T::traits_type, Appendices...>(std::allocator_arg, alloc, std::move(sink), std::forward<Appendices>(appendices)...).
code-item.remark: This overload shall not participate in overload resolution unless Sink is deemed to be an acceptable sink of T.
These overloads shall not participate in overload resolution unless c.insert(c.end(), t) is a valid expression where c is an lvalue of Container and t is an rvalue of typename Container::value_type.
